div.p: hi everyone I'm Cathy ding and I'm here
to talk to you about avoiding apps so as
a disclaimer I'm not like railing
against all apps i actually love apps i
love google maps i love snapchat i love
Instagram but that's not what I'm
talking about here I'm talking about
volunteer Civic apps um and I think it's
really easy for people to kind of equate
Civic tech and civic apps when people
talk about civic apps um they'll they'll
always talk about like the technology
first and also there's like no shortage
of hackathons and amp competitions that
kind of like elevate apps as something
you should aspire to um but I think that
tech can mean a lot of things and apps
are just a tiny tiny sliver um and one
thing about apps is that they're really
hard to make there's a reason why
instagram has like a giant team of paid
engineers so while apps are great i
don't think they're they're the best fit
for volunteer projects and also there's
a kind of more subtle issue with
focusing on apps which is that apps are
often not inclusive it's really hard to
get a volunteer project that's a nap and
also involve a lot of people who are not
developers because having apps just
really privileges coating over other
types of work um so anyways let's talk
about some other types of cool projects
that aren't app so if you're looking to
volunteer here and you're like not
really sure how here are a bunch of free
breakout group ideas um so one thing I
love is Bob so Bob are much more
lightweight than apps and require much
less maintenance what I really like is a
Twitter bot called census Americans a
lot of census data is like aggregate
data it'll be like the per capita income
of this zip code is X and it's hard to
see the people behind it so the spot
kind of personalizes and humanizes the
people behind behind the data
so hey I carpool with another person I
served during the Vietnam and Korea and
era it's kind of cool to see um another
type of bot you can make it doesn't have
to be a Twitter bot is live but um
here's about we have an art slackware if
you address a group of people that are
not all guys as guys it'll say hey did
you mean nerds or Pete and also the code
for this is on github we've been
thinking a lot about ways to automate
kind of having people introduce
themselves or give a little orientation
when people join our slack channels if
that's something you want to work on
talk to me another thing I love is
tutorial so we have a blog at hack night
and the first post on our blog was a
tutorial about web scraping and
tutorials are really cool because you
can learn a small thing but then share
it with a bunch of people and I also
think super simple web sites are really
underrated relative to apps um so this
is something we worked on at hack night
we did most of the work for this in like
one evening and is really fun because a
lot of the work wasn't coding we got
like 15 people together and everyone was
like researching articles about the
Illinois budget crisis and they show up
here uh and then another thing that you
can do with documentation so tech
projects involve a lot more than code
communication is also really important
but it's often undervalued and a lot of
projects it's hard for an outsider to
figure out like what is this even and
like how can I help so if you want to
help do that that's awesome too this is
another example that I love ah so this
is mystery shopping City Hall so you get
a bunch of people and make you things
like try to get a permit or try to get
water turned on and then you you kind of
log your experience and talk about how
difficult it was and I think this
involves no code whatsoever but I think
it's a really cool tech project because
it requires a pretty holistic view of
what a digital process should be and now
go forth and
